verses.text: Blessed is the husband of a good wife, for the number of his days will be doubled.
verses.comment: This verse highlights the profound blessing of marital harmony, linking the goodness of a wife with the extension of life itself. The scriptural idea of marriage as a covenant mirrors Christ’s relationship with the Church. See Eph 5:25.

verses.text: A loyal wife brings happiness to her husband, and he will complete his years in peace.
verses.comment: The value of fidelity in marriage is emphasized, suggesting a holy peace. This foreshadows the peace given in union with Christ, the Bridegroom.

verses.text: A good wife is a great blessing; she will be granted to a man who fears the Lord.
verses.comment: The connection between the fear of the Lord and receiving spiritual blessings is underscored. Marital grace is often understood as an image of divine favor for those who walk uprightly.

verses.text: Whether rich or poor, his heart is glad, and his face is cheerful at all times.
verses.comment: True joy does not depend on wealth but springs from a peaceful home and upright living. Spiritual contentment is a fruit of living faithfully.

verses.text: Of three things my heart is frightened, and a fourth causes me to panic: the accusation in the city, the gathering of a mob, and false charges—all worse than death.
verses.comment: The threat of false accusation recalls later episodes, such as the unjust treatment of Christ and early disciples. Slander and mob aggression are spiritual dangers as well as societal ones.

verses.text: But it is the pain of a rival wife, jealous and full of accusations—this is a suffering far worse than any of them.
verses.comment: Reference to rivalry among wives ties back to Old Testament stories, such as Rachel and Leah, showing spiritual consequences of jealousy within families.

verses.text: A harsh tongue is worse than any scourge. Falling into the hands of the wicked is as heavy as death.
verses.comment: The damage of words is compared to physical violence, echoing James 3:6 on the danger of the tongue. Both literal and spiritual wounds ensue from wickedness and calumny.

verses.text: It is hard to bear an evil wife, the burden laid upon her husband is continual.
verses.comment: This practical advice against enduring evil reflects on the disorder caused by moral failure. The text assumes the sanctity of marriage and the spiritual need for harmony.

verses.text: A drunken wife brings disgrace, her shame will not be hidden.
verses.comment: Drunkenness symbolizes loss of self-control and spiritual disarray; the shame here touches both family and communal life.

verses.text: An impudent wife will be recognized by the rolling of her eyes; she will be known by her expression.
verses.comment: Outward behavior betrays inward disposition. This verse underscores ancient wisdom concerning integrity and modesty.

verses.text: Keep strict watch over a headstrong daughter, lest she make you a laughingstock to your enemies, a topic of gossip in the town, and a source of shame among the people.
verses.comment: Parental vigilance is seen as a guard against scandal, a timeless principle. Early formation and discipline are recurring themes in wisdom literature.

verses.text: Do not let her beauty captivate you, or let her passions lead you to ruin.
verses.comment: A warning against temptation and lust, which recalls Joseph's resistance to Potiphar's wife and reinforces the call for purity.

verses.text: A wife’s charm brightens her husband’s face, and her understanding refreshes his bones.
verses.comment: The virtues of beauty and wisdom are inseparable in holy marriage. The spiritual interpretation refers to the soul adorned by grace.

verses.text: A silent wife is a gift from the Lord, and nothing is worth more than self-control.
verses.comment: Silence is correlated with wisdom, echoing themes in Proverbs and Psalms. Self-control is presented as a divine gift that leads to holiness.

verses.text: A modest wife is grace upon grace, no price can measure her worth.
verses.comment: Here, grace is spoken of in abundance—a foreshadowing of the New Testament’s teaching about walking in newness of life through spiritual gifts.

verses.text: As the sun rising in the Lord’s heavens, so is the beauty of a virtuous wife in her home.
verses.comment: Virtue is likened to the glory of creation. The home becomes a sanctified place, echoing the Church as the dwelling of holiness.

verses.text: A shining lamp on a holy lampstand is her beauty; a home set on a high hill.
verses.comment: Imagery reminiscent of Jesus’ parable about the lampstand, symbolizing how virtue and grace elevate the home.

verses.text: Beautiful feet are like pillars of gold, set on bases of silver.
verses.comment: Describes dignity of appearance; but spiritually, the feet represent walking in goodness, echoing the messengers who bring good news.

verses.text: My soul takes delight in three things, which are beautiful before both the Lord and men: harmony among brothers, friendship among neighbors, and the wife and husband who live together in unity.
verses.comment: Unity is praised everywhere in scripture as a mark of God’s people. The family is thus a living image of the Church’s unity with Christ.

verses.text: But sinners' gatherings are like burnt pieces of wood, thrown together, which shall be consumed by fire.
verses.comment: This image connects to the judgment metaphor in the New Testament, where the unfruitful are likened to chaff burned with unquenchable fire.

verses.text: A wicked wife is compared to a decaying ox yoke; grabbing her is like holding a scorpion.
verses.comment: The symbolic comparison points to spiritual consequences of persistent sin. There is also a warning about discernment in choosing companions.

verses.text: A drunken wife is great provocation; she will not hide her shame.
verses.comment: Repeated emphasis on the effects of vice, highlighting the spiritual and social dangers posed by disorder.

verses.text: A woman's lack of modesty reveals her nature; the way she walks discloses her heart.
verses.comment: Modesty is praised as a reflection of the soul. Externals manifest internals; this harmony is important for spiritual formation.

verses.text: A woman who honors her husband will be judged wise by all; but the one who dishonors him disgraces herself in the eyes of everyone.
verses.comment: This builds on the theme of reciprocal respect, central to biblical teaching about love and submission in marriage. A reflection of Christ’s model of self-giving.

verses.text: A shameless wife will be abandoned by her husband, but one with humility will gain honor.
verses.comment: Humility is esteemed as a path to honor, correlating with Jesus’ teachings on humility and exaltation. This reflects depths of spiritual wisdom.

verses.text: A wife who speaks wisely builds up her husband; her prudence will set his bones straight.
verses.comment: Wisdom in speech is a source of strength and edification, foreshadowing the role of God’s Word in forming and upholding believers.

verses.text: Sturdy legs and graceful feet are like everlasting pillars set upon a solid foundation.
verses.comment: Psalm imagery is used here, blending physical and spiritual stability. Foundation language hints at apostolic teaching and tradition as a source of spiritual strength.

verses.text: So the soul of a good wife is a lasting foundation; for her character will stand firm.
verses.comment: This verse confirms the centrality of faith, virtue, and steadfastness—qualities essential for perseverance in spiritual life.

verses.text: A husband who acquires a good wife receives the finest of blessings, she is the helper most pleasing to him.
verses.comment: Completing the chapter, marriage is again depicted as divinely appointed companionship; 'helper' echoes Genesis 2:18 and points towards an understanding of this sacramental relationship as instituted by God for our good.
